content.raw:
It seems that we can get/set the wind parameters with `SetParam()`/`Param()` and dedicated accessors. E.g.:

  * `Param("linear_vel");`
  * `LinearVel();`

Is there any reason for not choosing just one way and eliminate the duplication?
content.html:
It seems that we can get/set the wind parameters with SetParam()/Param() and dedicated accessors. E.g.:

  • Param("linear_vel");
  • LinearVel();

Is there any reason for not choosing just one way and eliminate the duplication?

content.raw: Do we need this accessor if we have the next one?
content.html: Do we need this accessor if we have the next one?

content.raw: Replace `_wind` with `_entity`.
content.html: Replace _wind with _entity.

content.html: I'm still trying to figure it out. I couldn't see any effect of the wind in the lift_drag_demo.world. It would be cool to make a test model of a wind chime (just a cylinder with LiftDragPlugin hanging from a ball joint)

content.html: Sure, I'm taking a look right now

update.description:
Gazebo does not have a Wind class. This pull request provides a simple Wind class whose default behavior can be overriden by a plugin.

The global wind parameters are defined in the SDF file, they consist of the wind linear velocity. The Wind class is instantiated once during World initialization. A plugin can access the Wind singleton with ```World::GetWind()``` and change its method of computation by specifying a custom function with ```Wind::SetLinearVelFunc(std::function<ignition::math::Vector3d (const WindPtr &, const Entity *_entity)> _linearVelFunc)```.

The wind velocity at a link position in space is updated before each simulation iteration by calling ```Wind::WorldLinearVel(const Entity *_entity)``` during world update. This method takes the entity itself as a parameter and returns the wind linear velocity at entity's current location. This operation is only performed if the wind is enabled globally and if the link is defined to be affected by it. Internally, this method calls the function that was determined by ```Wind::SetLinearVelFunc(...)```.

If it gets accepted, this feature would require two new optional sections in the link and world SDF files  (see related pull request [#240](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/240/new-element/diff) in sdformat):

```
#!xml
<world name="default">
  <wind>
    <linear_velocity>11 11 0</linear_velocity> <!-- Wind linear velocity -->
  </wind>
  <model name="model">
    <link name="link">
      <wind>true</<wind>
    </link>
  </model>
</world>
```

At the client side, the wind parameters are displayed in the property tree browser. Wind velocity for a selected link only appears in its corresponding property tree if the wind is enabled for this link.

A plugin example can be found in `plugins/WindPlugin.cc`. Its corresponding world is `worlds/wind_demo.world`.
update.title: Added wind support

content.raw:
Remove `inline`, and move implementation to source. 

I believe `inline` is only useful if a function is both small and used a lot. This matches the small criteria, but I don't think it matches the second.

We'll also remove inline when we PIMPL-ize this class.
content.html:
Remove inline, and move implementation to source.

I believe inline is only useful if a function is both small and used a lot. This matches the small criteria, but I don't think it matches the second.

We'll also remove inline when we PIMPL-ize this class.

content.raw: `std::bind(&Link::UpdateWind, this, std::placeholders::_1));`
content.html: std::bind(&Link::UpdateWind, this, std::placeholders::_1));

Gazebo does not have a Wind class. This pull request provides a simple Wind class whose default behavior can be overriden by a plugin.

The global wind parameters are defined in the SDF file, they consist of the wind linear velocity. The Wind class is instantiated once during World initialization. A plugin can access the Wind singleton with ```World::GetWind()``` and change its method of computation by specifying a custom function with ```Wind::SetLinearVelFunc(std::function<ignition::math::Vector3d (const WindPtr &, const Entity *_entity)> _linearVelFunc)```.

The wind velocity at a link position in space is updated before each simulation iteration by calling ```Wind::WorldLinearVel(const Entity *_entity)``` during world update. This method takes the entity itself as a parameter and returns the wind linear velocity at entity's current location. This operation is only performed if the wind is enabled globally and if the link is defined to be affected by it. Internally, this method calls the function that was determined by ```Wind::SetLinearVelFunc(...)```.

If it gets accepted, this feature would require two new optional sections in the link and world SDF files  (see related pull request [#240](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/240/new-element/diff) in sdformat):

```
#!xml
<world name="default">
  <wind>
    <linear_velocity>11 11 0</linear_velocity> <!-- Wind linear velocity -->
  </wind>
  <model name="model">
    <link name="link">
      <wind>true</<wind>
    </link>
  </model>
</world>
```

At the client side, the wind parameters are displayed in the property tree browser. Wind velocity for a selected link only appears in its corresponding property tree if the wind is enabled for this link.

A plugin example can be found in `plugins/WindPlugin.cc`. Its corresponding world is `worlds/wind_demo.world`.
update.title: Added wind support

content.html:
@ocrave, Thanks for this new feature. We've been upgrading our style a bit with the following rules:

  1. Don't prefix a member accessors with "Get". For example World::GetWind() const should be World::Wind() const. Keep using the Set prefix for mutators.

  2. Use const for all parameters that do not to change in a function. For example, Model::SetWindMode(bool _mode) should be Model::SetWindMode(const bool _mode).

content.raw: This doesn't make physical sense to me. I think we could come up with a demo that is more physically based, perhaps by connecting with the `LiftDragPlugin`?
content.html: This doesn't make physical sense to me. I think we could come up with a demo that is more physically based, perhaps by connecting with the LiftDragPlugin?

update.description:
Gazebo does not have a Wind class. This pull request provides a simple Wind class whose default behavior can be overriden by a plugin.

The global wind parameters are defined in the SDF file, they consist of the wind direction and magnitude. The Wind class is instantiated once during World initialization. A plugin can access the Wind singleton with ```World::GetWind()``` and change its method of computation by specifying a custom function with ```Wind::SetLinearVelFunc(std::function<ignition::math::Vector3d (const WindPtr &, const Entity *_entity)> _linearVelFunc)```.

The wind velocity at a link position in space is updated before each simulation iteration by calling ```Wind::WorldLinearVel(const Entity *_entity)``` during world update. This method takes the entity itself as a parameter and returns the wind linear velocity at entity's current location. This operation is only performed if the wind is enabled globally and if the link is defined to be affected by it. Internally, this method calls the function that was determined by ```Wind::SetLinearVelFunc(...)```.

If it gets accepted, this feature would require two new optional sections in the link and world SDF files  (see related pull request [#240](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/240/new-element/diff) in sdformat):

```
#!xml
<world name="default">
  <wind>
    <direction>45.0</direction> <!-- Wind direction in unit of degrees -->
    <magnitude>15.0</magnitude> <!-- Wind magnitude in world units -->
  </wind>
  <model name="model">
    <link name="link">
      <wind>true</<wind>
    </link>
  </model>
</world>
```

At the client side, the wind parameters are displayed in the property tree browser. Wind velocity for a selected link only appears in its corresponding property tree if the wind is enabled for this link.

A plugin example can be found in `plugins/WindPlugin.cc`. Its corresponding world is `worlds/wind_demo.world`.
